image.altText: An illustration shows a mosaic of personal data, with a search field for email addresses.

items.synopsis: Have you ever wondered how much of your personal information is available online? Here's your chance to find out.

title.children: Find out what data is available about you online — but be warned, it might feel a little creepy

image.altText: A man with a medium-length beard wearing a black beanie, headphones around his neck and a grey hoodie

items.synopsis: With New Zealand police now treating the fatal fire at a Wellington hostel as arson, former residents recall how they managed to escape the burning building and the stark conditions inside.

title.children: 'Pretty effing disgusted': Wellington hostel residents lament lives lost over suspected arson

image.altText: Don Matheson with a football team logo behind him

items.synopsis: The former owner of the Northern Queensland Fury football club, Don Matheson, is now at the centre of a joint investigation between Papua New Guinea police, Interpol, and Australian authorities.

title.children: Former A-league club owner and Australian entrepreneur investigated after ABC revelations

image.altText: An illustration of a woman undergoing a mammogram.

items.synopsis: Breast density isn't related to breast size, nor can it be determined by touch or feel — and there's debate over whether women should know about it.

title.children: One in 10 women has 'extremely dense breasts' — and it can affect cancer risk. Here's what you need to know

image.altText: Prince harry in an open-collard shirt and grey jacket, holds hands with his wife Meghan in a beige halter neck

items.synopsis: The office of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex says the prince, his wife and her mother were followed for more than two hours by half a dozen vehicles after leaving a charity event in New York on Tuesday.

title.children: Prince Harry and Meghan pursued by paparazzi in what they call a 'near catastrophic car chase'

image.altText: A paparazzi photographs Prince Harry at nighttime

items.synopsis: After a lifetime of camera flashes and intimate front-page spreads, this is the story of how Prince Harry became an enemy of the tabloid media.

title.children: The long history of bad blood between Prince Harry and the media

image.altText: A man in an apron holds a large, weathered old book up for display.

items.synopsis: This is The Loop, your quick catch-up for this morning's stories as they happened.

title.children: Hebrew bible sells for $57 million, Rugby Australia backs Voice to Parliament, Chinese comedy group fined $3m for Xi joke. Catch up with The Loop

image.altText: Shane Drumgold holding a folder walking into ACAT. He is wearing sunglasses and shot is side-on.

items.synopsis: The ACT Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) Shane Drumgold has been replaced in the position while the board of inquiry into the handling of the Bruce Lehrmann case continues.

title.children: ACT chief prosecutor Shane Drumgold temporarily replaced amid inquiry into Bruce Lehrmann's trial

image.altText: A street sign that says "Coonalpyn" in front of a painted silo.

items.synopsis: Some South Australian councils are planning rate rises of up to 10 per cent this coming financial year and farmers are facing some of the largest increases.

title.children: Farmers to bear the brunt as SA council rates increase by up to 10 per cent

image.altText: A school bus rolled onto its side with the impact of a crash visible, with emergency services walking behind.

items.synopsis: As Melbourne's outer-suburban sprawl has inched towards Exford Primary, the school has retained its country feel — and it was a sense of community that kicked in after Tuesday's horror bus crash.

title.children: 'Everyone's really sad and worried about their friends': School bus crash leaves community in shock

image.altText: Firefighter in Baldivis - good generic

items.synopsis: The threat eases from a bushfire that had been burning toward homes in Whitby in the Shire of Serpentine-Jarrahdale, with an emergency warning downgraded to a watch and act.

title.children: Emergency warning lifted as threat eases from out-of-control bushfire in Perth's south-east

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit with glasses speaks behind a microphone-laden lectern in front of the Sydney Opera House.

items.synopsis: Anthony Albanese's biggest challenge, a year after being sworn in as PM, has been dealing with global uncertainty — this week in the form of the US being gripped by the "blocking and disruption" of its polarised domestic politics, writes David Speers.

title.children: Joe Biden bailing on Australia is a reminder of Albanese's biggest challenge as PM

image.altText: two men close up

items.synopsis: Independent MP Alex Greenwich had previously threatened to sue Mark Latham for defamation if the One Nation MP did not apologise or attempt to make amends.

title.children: 'It's 2023': Independent MP Alex Greenwich to sue for defamation over Mark Latham's offensive tweet

image.altText: Sylvia Massara in her home, pictured with her cat

items.synopsis: A charity-run housing estate will raise rental prices by 10 per cent – which residents like Sylvia Massara will struggle to afford.

title.children: Australia's rental market tightens further as rental price increases reach 30 per cent in some areas

image.altText: Jason De Ieso was murdered in late 2012

items.synopsis: A witness tells the Supreme Court he saw people wearing hoodies walking towards the northern Adelaide workshop with what appeared to be guns.

title.children: 'I narrowly missed a shot': Jason De Ieso murder trial told witnesses saw hooded men open fire in workshop

image.altText: Text on an iPhone screen reads: "It looks like you've been in a crash. iPhone will trigger Emergency SOS if you don't respond."

items.synopsis: An automated emergency message sent from a phone after a crash in Port Augusta has led to the arrest of a teenager alleged to have been driving under the influence.

title.children: iPhone alerts police to alleged drunk driver in SA

image.altText: Gene Charles Bristow mug shot

items.synopsis: Gene Bristow — who had lured a 24-year-old European backpacker to his Meningie farm, south-east of Adelaide, and raped her — refuses to pay the victims of crime levy because he is not an Australian citizen.

title.children: SA man who kidnapped and raped backpacker refuses to pay victims of crime levy

image.altText: A man wears a lanyard with the Australian Government coat of arms on it.

items.synopsis: Labor has set itself a modest target for winding back government spending on external contractors, but it may prove much tougher to meet than expected.

title.children: Public servants may get a real pay rise, but it's unlikely to lure contractors back

image.altText: Nighttime photo of two cars in highway accident

items.synopsis: The death of a man in his 80s who was travelling along a dangerous stretch of road in the NSW South Coast has reignited the community's calls for an urgent road upgrade.

title.children: Fatal crash on notorious highway stretch highlights urgent need for long-promised upgrade

image.altText: A hippo yawning at a lake in Kenya.

items.synopsis: Seven people are dead and a further 17 are still missing after a hippopotamus capsized a boat in Malawi, Africa.

title.children: Two teenagers among seven people dead after hippo capsizes boat

image.altText: Woman in a pink fur coat wearing gold glasses with dollar signs on the front of the frames.

items.synopsis: If assisted reproductive technology is going to help our future fertility problems, should the government be helping women cover the costs of this pricey procedure? Some doctors say yes, others say it's a "can of worms".

title.children: Costs remain a barrier to egg freezing, so should the government subsidise it?

image.altText: A blurry headshot of a dark-haired, dark-eyed man in his 30s.

items.synopsis: Civilian witnesses and a police officer have told a coronial inquest they believe the officer who fatally shot 31-year-old Benjamin Madex in Drouin in January 2021 had no other option.

title.children: Police officer had no choice but to open fire on man brandishing knife, inquest hears

image.altText: A smashed police car against a guard rail on a highway backlit by a spotlight

items.synopsis: Officers found a woman in her 20s who had been stabbed and she later died in hospital. The driver of a Holden Commodore, who police officers linked to the death, has been arrested.

image.altText: Jazeer Nijamudeen wears a suit jacket and stands looking seriously in front of a fence and soil.

items.synopsis: At the Allura estate in Melbourne, like in many new housing developments, residents say they've waited years for infrastructure. The Consumer Action Law Centre is now calling on the state government to toughen laws for developers.

title.children: Residents bought into this estate on the promise of a bustling town centre. A decade later, it's still empty land

image.altText: a man stands next to a large blue puppet

items.synopsis: It's called the biggest little show on Earth, and Bluey has taken Toowoomba's Chris White across the world, performing on iconic stages as a puppeteer in the stage show.

title.children: Meet the young Aussie actor stepping into the shoes — or paws — of one of Australia's most beloved characters

image.altText: Titanic revealed in first-ever 3D scans of shipwreck

items.synopsis: Deep-sea mappers hope the 3D scan of the wreck of the Titanic may reveal more details about the ocean liner's fateful journey across the Atlantic more than a century ago.

title.children: Titanic shipwreck on the seabed visualised for first time in 3D scan

image.altText: A man holding his foot up to the camera.

items.synopsis: When Peter Bedford, 74, decided to seek treatment for a fungal toenail, he had no idea it would lead to major heart surgery.

title.children: How a trip to the podiatrist for a fungal toenail saved Peter's life

image.altText: A woman with short hair and glasses stands  in front of a house

items.synopsis: Tenants caught up in the housing crisis are being advised to stay in their rentals after being served with notices to vacate so they can buy more time to search for new accommodation.

title.children: Terrified of being homeless, Joanne stayed in her rental and waited for a court order

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

items.synopsis: Wall Street and the ASX have bounced upwards as US President Joe Biden reassures his citizens that "America will not default". Meanwhile, jobs data is out in Australia.

title.children: Joe Biden reassures that 'America will not default', pushing up US and Australian sharemarkets

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Looks like that optimism in Wall Street has spread to Australia. Both major indexes here are making strong gains on open, with both the All Ords and ASX 200 surging 0.8% on open. The biggest gains are in mining, including iron ore and lithium. Meanwhile, we have losses in the gas industry and some retail stocks, including Lovida. This is all ahead of the jobs data set to be released by the ABS at 11:30am AEST. We know that the Reserve Bank will be closely watching this data for signs that its ploy to tackle inflation is working or not. Here's a take by our colleague Peter Ryan. We'll also have my colleague Michael Janda on deck as the ABS jobs data is being released to answer your questions. Start sending them through on the comments!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian shares follow Wall Street higher

children.content: Looks like that optimism in Wall Street has spread to Australia.
Both major indexes here are making strong gains on open, with both the All Ords and ASX 200 surging 0.8% on open.
The biggest gains are in mining, including iron ore and lithium.
Meanwhile, we have losses in the gas industry and some retail stocks, including Lovida.
This is all ahead of the jobs data set to be released by the ABS at 11:30am AEST.
We know that the Reserve Bank will be closely watching this data for signs that its ploy to tackle inflation is working or not.
Here's a take by our colleague Peter Ryan.
We'll also have my colleague Michael Janda on deck as the ABS jobs data is being released to answer your questions.
Start sending them through on the comments!
The ASX 200 at 10:30am AEST.
(Eikon/Reuters)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning! While you were sleeping, there was a bounce of optimism in the United States, as its citizens were reassured by their president that "America will not default". "I’m confident that we'll get the agreement on the budget," Joe Biden added. The United States is facing the prospect of defaulting on trillions of dollars worth of loans, unless the Republicans and Democrats strike a deal to legally allow the US Department of Treasury to incur more debt, which would allow it to pay its bills. US Treasury officials say that, unless a deal is reached, the US risks running out of money to pay its debts as soon as June 1, and this could trigger a recession, sparking fears of a global economic and financial crisis. But those comments by Biden have seemed to soothe equity markets there, at least, for now. And of course, Australian shares are set to follow. Meanwhile, the US dollar rose overnight, pushing the Australian currency against the greenback slightly down to 66.62 US cents. Let's hope those sixes aren't ominous. Here in Australia, we have labour force data out at 11:30am AEST. Will Australia’s unemployment remain steady at near a 50 year low of 3.5 per cent, or will we start to get an uptick as interest rates crimp demand? We'll be here keeping you updated.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: US equities up as Biden reassures that 'America will not default'

featuredLink.title: 'It's a really huge deal': Why the US debt ceiling crisis has implications for Australia

children.content: Good morning!
While you were sleeping, there was a bounce of optimism in the United States, as its citizens were reassured by their president that "America will not default".
"I’m confident that we'll get the agreement on the budget," Joe Biden added.

The United States is facing the prospect of defaulting on trillions of dollars worth of loans, unless the Republicans and Democrats strike a deal to legally allow the US Department of Treasury to incur more debt, which
would allow it to pay its bills.
US Treasury officials say that, unless a deal is reached, the US risks running out of money to pay its debts as soon as June 1, and this
could trigger a recession, sparking fears of a global economic and financial crisis.
But those comments by Biden have seemed to soothe equity markets there, at least, for now.
And of course, Australian shares are set to follow.
Meanwhile, the US dollar rose overnight, pushing the Australian currency against the greenback slightly down to 66.62 US cents. Let's hope those sixes aren't ominous.

Here in Australia, we have labour force data out at 11:30am AEST. Will Australia’s unemployment remain steady at near a 50 year low of 3.5 per cent, or will we start to get an uptick as interest rates crimp demand?
We'll be here keeping you updated.

image.altText: Woman with hair in bun and blue cardigan wearing glasses sitting down

items.synopsis: A group of senior legal academics from New South Wales and Victoria write to the NSW attorney-general, urging him to use his power to immediately release Kathleen Folbigg from prison.

title.children: Senior academics call for early release of Kathleen Folbigg

image.altText: Two men sitting in front of a kitchen. The man on the left wears a plaid shirt and the man on the right a green t-shirt.

items.synopsis: Two tradesmen who ran to help at the site of Tuesday's school bus crash in Melbourne tell of the horrific scenes they faced as they tried to rescue the children.

title.children: Children in bus crash found yelling 'where's mum?' when rescuers arrived

image.altText: Three little girls give a peace sign while a man takes a photo

items.synopsis: Known as the forbidden kingdom, Bhutan is famous for its national pursuit of happiness and for being carbon negative. But it is also caught between two feuding giants.

title.children: Sandwiched between two feuding superpowers, Bhutan, the happiest nation on Earth has a choice to make

image.altText: Olena Fedosieieva, in bright red shirt, stands with hands in pockets in front of lush, green trees smiling.

items.synopsis: Despite growing up with Russian as her dominant language, Olena Fedosieieva has now largely ditched the language in a show of solidarity. And she's far from alone.

title.children: 'When you speak Russian, you have a great pain.' At 48, Olena decided to switch languages and she's not alone

image.altText: A composite image of small metal and plastic bands removed from magpies, and a magpie fitted with the tags holding its leg up.

items.synopsis: Victoria's Conservation Regulator is investigating reports of birds tagged with what are thought to be illegal bands in Melbourne's west. In the meantime, a concerned resident has stepped in to rescue them.

title.children: 'Distressed' magpies fitted with 'homemade' tags prompt animal cruelty investigation
